## Soundness and Completeness

We have now completed the three tasks involved in formalizing the central notions of logic that we set for ourselves at the beginning of this chapter. Accordingly, we are now in a position to express the two questions that we raised there in purely mathematical terms. These questions, recall, were:

1. Is a given method of reasoning such as to result in only valid inferences or, by employing that method, can one sometimes be led to draw invalid inferences as well?

2. Are there some valid inferences in a given domain which, in principle, cannot result from applying a given method of reasoning, or are all such inferences invalid?

Having made mathematically precise the various notions implicated in these
questions, we can interpret them in strictly mathematical terms. When
we ask, for example, 'does a given method of reasoning ever lead to invalid
inferences?', we are asking of a given proof system whether it is possible for a
sentence $\ph$ to be provable from $\Gamma$ in that system, despite the fact
that $\ph$ is not a logical consequence of $\Gamma$. We refer to the property of
a proof system which denies this possibility as soundness.

:::{#def-soundness data-re="sound" data-flags="gi"}
A proof system $\mathbf{D}$ is _sound_ if, for any set of sentences $\Gamma$ and any sentence $\ph$: if $\Gamma\proves_\mathbf{D} \ph$, then $\Gamma\models \ph$.
:::

Conversely, when we ask 'do there exist valid inferences which cannot result
from a given method of reasoning?', we are asking of a given proof system
whether it is possible for a sentence $\ph$ to be a logical consequence of
$\Gamma$ despite the fact that $\ph$ is not provable from $\Gamma$ in that
system. The property which denies this possibility is referred to as
_completeness_.

:::{#def-completeness data-re="completeness" data-flags="gi"} 
A proof system $\mathbf{D}$ is _complete_ if, for any set of sentences $\Gamma$
and any sentence $\ph$: if $\Gamma\models \ph$, then
$\Gamma\proves_\mathbf{D}\ph$.
:::

Taken together, the soundness and completeness of a proof system means
that an argument is valid if and only if its conclusion is provable in that
system from its premises. When we have shown this, we know that the proof system codifies exactly the system of inferences validated by the intended meanings of the logical elements of the syntax. Thus, when we reason by giving proofs in this system, we can be sure that, in so doing, there is no principled threat of error or omission.[^Godel]

[^Godel]: The existence of a sound and complete proof system for first-order
quantificational logic was proven by Kurt GÃ¶del in his doctoral dissertation
of 1929. This is often regarded as one of the first foundational results in
mathematical logic.

In upcoming chapters, we will be studying proof systems across a wide variety of
syntactic and semantic contexts and we will show that these systems are both
sound and complete. In the course of doing so, it will quickly become evident
that there exists a stark asymmetry in the relative difficulty of these two tasks. To show that a proof system is sound is, in general, a rather easy
task, but to show that it is complete is often quite difficult and requires some
degree of mathematical ingenuity. Why this asymmetry? 

The soundness of a proof system $\mathbf{D}$ asserts that, for any arbitrary set of sentences $\Ga$, every sentence that is
a deductive consequence of $\Ga$ in $\mathbf{D}$ is a logical consequence of
$\Ga$. Completeness, on the other hand, asserts that every logical consequence
of $\Ga$ is a deductive consequence of $\Ga$. The relative ease with which
soundness results can be proven when compared to completeness results is owing
to the fact that, unlike the set of all logical consequences of $\Ga$, that is:
$$
\{\ph: \Ga\models\ph\}
$$
the set of all deductive consequences of $\Ga$:
$$
\{\ph: \Ga\proves_{\mathbf{D}}\ph\}
$$
can be given a straightforward inductive definition, as follows:  

1. If $\ph\in\Ga$, then $\Ga\proves_\mathbf{D}\ph$.

2. If $\ph$ is an axiom of $\mathbf{D}$, then $\Ga\proves_\mathbf{D}\ph$. 

3. If $\Ga\proves_\mathbf{D}\ph_i$, for $i=1,\ldots,n$, and $\psi$ follows from $\ph_1,\ldots,\ph_n$ by some rule of inference of $\mathbf{D}$, then $\Ga\proves_\mathbf{D}\psi$. 

<!-- TODO: Add exercise on converting trees to proofs -->

Accordingly, the soundness of a proof system can generally be established by the method of [proof by induction](@sec-proof-by-induction). To establish soundness we must show that every sentence in the set $\{\ph: \Ga\proves_{\mathbf{D}}\ph\}$ has the property of being a logical consequence of $\Ga$. Appealing to the above inductive definition of this set, it suffices to show:

1. If $\ph\in\Ga$, then $\Ga\models\ph$.

2. If $\ph$ is an axiom of $\mathbf{D}$, then $\Ga\models\ph$. 

3. If $\Ga\models\ph_i$, for $i=1,\ldots,n$, and $\psi$ follows from $\ph_1,\ldots,\ph_n$ by some rule of inference of $\mathbf{D}$, then $\Ga\models\psi$. 

Clause 1 is a direct consequence of our definition of validity, and so may be taken for granted---see @thm-semantic-structure.(i). Moreover, it suffices to establish clause 3 to show that if $\psi$ follows from $\ph_1,\ldots,\ph_n$, by some rule of inference of $\mathbf{D}$, then:
$$
\ph_1,\ldots,\ph_n\models\psi
$$

For, if $\Ga\models\ph_i$, for $i=1,\ldots,n$, by repeated applications of @thm-semantic-structure.(iii), it follows that $\Ga\models\psi$. 

Hence, to establish the soundness of a proof system $\mathbf{D}$ it suffices to show: 

1. If $\ph$ is an axiom of $\mathbf{D}$, then $\Ga\models\ph$. 

2. If $\psi$ follows from $\ph_1,\ldots,\ph_n$ by some rule of inference of $\mathbf{D}$, then $\ph_1,\ldots,\ph_n\models\psi$. 

This simple strategy for establishing soundness is available because the idea of
a proof is itself inductive in nature: proofs are built up from the axioms and
premises of an argument through the repeated application of the rules of
inference. The idea of validity, by contrast, is not inductive. The valid
arguments are not built up recursively, but are rather defined, in negative
existential terms, as those arguments which lack a semantic counterexample. As
such, there is no obvious way to establish the completeness of a proof system by
the method of induction. As we shall see in upcoming chapters, completeness
results require a defter touch.
